repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Information Infrastructure and
            Applications Development Project (IIADP)

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Information
            Infrastructure and Applications Development Project (IIADP)
            for Indonesia was satisfactory, the sustainability was
            likely, the institutional development impact was modest, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            The lessons learned were that: 1) project management
            increases in complexity when several ministries and agencies
            are involved in essentially cross-sectoral projects, so the
            number of agencies should be limited as much as possible and
            pro-active coordination mechanism established with
            sufficient procurement and financial management
            capabilities; 2) to secure the benefits of improved access
            to information and services available to governmental,
            ministerial, scientific, educational, and technical research
            communities, future projects should examine options such as
            taking advantage of commercial methods of financing
            investment in networks, outsourcing to private suppliers,
            and improving the effectiveness of regulation; 3) training
            and re-training of Project Management Implementation Unit
            (PMIU)s in Bank procurement guidelines is needed to enhance
            the quality and speed of the procurement process and to
            effectively address procurement problems. This is especially
            important for new agencies implementing the Bank's
            project for the first time; 4) from the Science and
            Technology Network of the Agency for the Assessment and
            Application of Technology (IPTEKnet)'s recent efforts
            to expand into the provinces, it became ever clearer that
            the Government of Indonesia (GOI) needs connectivity
            throughout the country, not just Jakarta. ; 5) continuity in
            the Bank's project team and the Coordinating Project
            Management Implementation Unit (CPMIU) can be critical for
            satisfactory project implementation; 6) pilot projects
            should have a clear methodology in place for scaling up and
            assessing viability for replication, and be backed by
            effective implementation and enforcement of policies and
            laws; 7) increasingly, the convergence of ICT services and
            markets necessitates a corresponding convergence of
            institutional authority to deal with the sector and to make
            most effective use of limited supply of high-caliber
            regulatory professionals; and 8) a systematic set of
            indicators should be agreed upon and established to monitor
            and evaluate both implementation of e-development projects
            and their impact on sector development.

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Information Infrastructure Development Project (IIDP) for
            Indonesia is to enhance private sector participation in
            providing information technology (IT), postal, and tourism
            services by removing barriers to entry. There are five
            components. The The first involves improving the legal and
            regulatory framework by providing advisory services,
            training, and equipment to prepare laws and regulations on
            intellectual property rights; carries out policy studies,
            trains staff, and strengthens the policy or institutional
            capacities of the state secretariat; improves the copyright,
            patent, and trademark directorate, as well as the national
            development planning agency. The second component enhances
            the efficiency and effectiveness of researchers by expanding
            the science and technology network. The third component,
            having two sub-components, strengthens the legal and
            regulatory framework to promote private sector participation
            in postal services; and extends tourist information services
            to the regions by developing the business model and pilot
            projects for an electronic tourism information system. The
            fourth and fifth components provide technical assistance and
            training to promote private participation and IT service
            delivery, and project management assistance, respectively.
